...
A Proclamacyon set forth for the Bue [execucyon] obseruacyon of the
Sabbothe Baye/
fforasmuche as not onely by the devyne preceptes, and lawes of almightie god,
but also by the kynges Maiestyes moost godly Iniunccyons and procedinges*
everye good christen man and woman, is streightly bounden to kepe holy
and sanctyfie the sabboth daye, Commonly called the Sondaye, and to come
vnto the churche, and other places appoynted for the same, to heare the
worde of god preached, and all maner of other dyvine service, there doen
and executed: And there accordynge to their moost duetyes to geve all
honor laude and prayse, vnto almightie god, the aucthor and geuer of all
goodnes, from whome onely all grace and goodnes commeth, procedeth &
spryngeth, & none other, for the great and manyfolde [goodnes] benefytes,
gyftes & graces, that they dayly haue, and doo receyve of him] Neuertheles
manye and dyuerse persones. hauing lytle respecte or regarde of their saide
moost bounden duetyes & obedience, towardes almightie god, and ther
said soueraign lorde kinges maiestie, but rather enclyning & geving theim
selfes to all sensuall and worldly pleasure, liberties & carnall lustes, of this
transitory worlde, in the tyme of dyvine service, saide, songe & mynistred,
and the woorde of god preached and declared, thei commonly vse to go to
brekefast, eating & drynking & other ryotous pastyme, & vnlawfull games
not onely to the highe dyspleasure of almightie god and their saide soueraign
lorde: but also to the evill, devilshe, and pernicious example of all others, and

to the greatt dyscommendacion and reproche of the governours and rulers
of this Cytie,] permytting and suffering the same, for the eschuinge and
abolysshing of whiche vngodly and detestable vses, enormyties and evills, so
commonlye vsed vpon the sondaye] And for the furtheraunce, and setting
furth of goddes holy worde, glory and honor, and of our saide Soueraign
lorde the kinges highnes moost godly procedinges, and the restraint and
punysshement of all suche parsons. as forgetting god do commonly breake
the Sabboth daye, called the Sondaye in forme aforesaide: My lorde Mayre
and my maisters his breathern thaldermen of this Cytie of london. vpon the
kinge our soueraign lordes behalf, streightly and Commaunde, all and all
maner of persone and persons, that kepe anye Tauerne Alehouse, Bearehowse,
or other vytailing howse, or place of common eating and drinking within
this Cytie [and] Suburbes and libertyes of the same, and also in the towne
and burroughe of Southwerke] that they from hencefurth, on everye Sondaye,
kepe their dores shutt in] And suffer no breakefastes or common eting [and]
or drinking within their howses, or other places of the same, duryng the
tyme of all maner of dyvine seruice or Sermon to be doen, ministered, or
made within their paryshe Churches or other the places therfore ordeigned
& provyded, vpon peyne of imprisonnement, of the bodyes, aswell of everye
suche howseholder, or other personnes vsing vytailing, as of all & everye
other personne and persones, that frequent or vse suche, eating, drynking,
playing or gamyng in anye suche place or places, contrarye to the Tenour,
purport, effect, and true meaning [of this] of this proclamacyon] And [suffer]
to suffer suche greuous punyshement as to the saide lorde mayer & his
breathern shalbe thought convenyent for their saide offences in breaking of
anye poinct of this proclamacion
God saue the kynge/

f 163MMay:) (Proclamation for the punishment of rebels)
. . .
eItem yf eny person vnleifullye by rynginge of belles or sownynge of
trompett droome horne or other instrument or by malicious speking/
outcrye] or any other acte do raise anye persons to the nomber of xij or
aboue to thintentt that thei shulde putt in vre anye of thactes aforesaide &
therevppon the said xij persons do contynue together as is aforesaid or doo
anye suche vnleifull acte as is aforesaide everye suche offendour shalbe iudged
a felon & suffer deth as a felon....

f 665r
By the Mayer
We woll and Comaunde yow vpon the kinge our soueraign Lordes behalf
that ye in either of the vigilles of Seynt lohn the Baptiste and Seynt Peter
and Paule next ensuyng do cause to be made within your said warde a good
and substancyall doble watche bothe of Constables & watchemen beyng
good [and] honest & dyscrett howseholders of the same warde well and
defencybly harnyssed and weaponed with out any maner of mynstralsy
light or lurnettes] or vsing anye other kynde of thinges vpon their bodyes
but onely good harnes in suche quyett maner as at other tymes of the yeare
is Comenly vsed [attending vpon theim]] The same watche to begynne at
ix of the clock in the Evenyng and so to contynue in good order vnto iiij
of the clock in the mornyng then next folowyng] And that yow contynue
& kepe your watches nightly at all other tymes according to our preceptes
heretofore to yow dyrectyd for the same] ffayle ye not this to do as ye will
aunswer at your vttermoost perylles Touen at the guyldhall the xxth daye
of lune Anno Regni Regis Edwarai vjti iiijto/

f 112.(7November)
. . .
Item it is orderyd that the ij Secondaries of the Compters Mr Atkyns & Mr
Burnell shall accordyng to the tenour of the recognysaunce lately taken [f]
before the Lorde grete master & remaynyng with my Lorde mayer] pervse
all suche enterludes as hereafter shalbe pleyed by eny comen pleyr of the
same within the Citie or the liberties therof] And make reporte of the same
to the Lorde mayer for the tyme beynge] And accordyng thervnto my Lorde
mayer to suffer them to go forwarde or to stey/

f 102.(28[anuary)
Item it is agreyd that master Chamberleyne shall pay & alowe to mr Lok
Alderman & mr Aylif xxxv s. for certein necessary charges by them leyd out
vpon the evyns [&] of the natyvitie of seynt lohn Baptyst & seynt Peter in
the tyme of their office of Shryvaltie of this , citie by reason of the styryng
& vnquyetnes of moche Rude people about that tyme] And not for eny
accustomyd duetie in that behalfe] or that it should be taken for eny precydent
herafter/
